conclusion: Shadows A, B, C, and D are cast by objects above the surface.
The light source is initially positioned forward, casting elongated shadows behind the objects.
When the light source moves backward, the direction of the light rays changes, causing the shadows to shift forward.
Moving the light source backward results in shorter shadows because the angle of incidence of the light rays increases.
The shadow A will move closer to the object and become shorter.
The shadow B will move forward and become shorter.
The shadow C will move forward and become shorter, similar to A and B.
The shadow D will also move forward and become shorter.
All shadows will shift closer to their respective objects.
The size of each shadow will decrease due to the increased angle of the light source relative to the objects.
When the light source moves backward, shadows A, B, C, and D will move closer to their respective objects and become shorter.
